 Yes I am going against the Old Testament. I am not under the law of the Old Testament. The Old Testament is important and it is full a many great things, but the New Testament does change, explain, elaborate and/or does away with certain things in the Old Testament. For example on the issue of unclean food, we just need to look at the book of Acts chapter 10 verses 9-16.
 
 9 On the morrow, as they went on their journey, and drew nigh unto the city, Peter went up upon the housetop to pray about the sixth hour:
 10 And he became very hungry, and would have eaten: but while they made ready, he fell into a trance,
 11 And saw heaven opened, and a certain vessel descending unto him, as it had been a great sheet knit at the four corners, and let down to the earth:
 12 Wherein were all manner of fourfooted beasts of the earth, and wild beasts, and creeping things, and fowls of the air.
 13 And there came a voice to him, Rise, Peter; kill, and eat.
 14 But Peter said, Not so, Lord; for I have never eaten any thing that is common or unclean.
 15 And the voice spake unto him again the second time, What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common.
 16 This was done thrice: and the vessel was received up again into heaven.
 KJV
 
 Here is an example of how something was change from the Old Testament to the New Testament. If you look throughout history to see how God acted, interacted, dealt with, and expected from mankind, it changes over time. The time frames, often called dispensations can be used to help us understand the differences. Things where one way from creation to Moses (the patriarchs), then there is Moses to Jesus (the Law), next Jesus to the rapture (Grace), followed by the millennial reign.
